content.text:
The main water line into a tall building has a pressure of 600 kPa at 5 m below ground level, as shown in<image 1>. A pump brings the pressure up so thatnthe water can be delivered at 200 kPa at the top floor 100 m above ground level. Assume a flow rate of 10 kg/s liquid water at 10°C and neglect any difference in kinetic energy and internal energy u. Find the pump work.

A. W' =-6.3MW
B. W' =-7.3MW
C. W' =-9.3MW

To find the pump work, we need to consider the change in pressure and the height difference between the water main and the top floor. The pump work can be calculated using the formula:

\[ W = \dot{m} \cdot (P_2 - P_1) + \dot{m} \cdot g \cdot h \]

where:
- \( \dot{m} \) is the mass flow rate (10 kg/s)
- \( P_1 \) is the initial pressure (600 kPa)
- \( P_2 \) is the final pressure (200 kPa at the top floor)
- \( g \) is the acceleration due to gravity (9.81 m/s²)
- \( h \) is the height difference (150 m)

First, convert the pressures from kPa to Pa:
- \( P_1 = 600 \times 10^3 \) Pa
- \( P_2 = 200 \times 10^3 \) Pa

Now, calculate the pump work:
\[ W = \dot{m} \cdot (P_2 - P_1) + \dot{m} \cdot g \cdot h \]
\[ W = 10 \cdot (200 \times 10^3 - 600 \times 10^3) + 10 \cdot 9.81 \cdot 150 \]
\[ W = 10 \cdot (-400 \times 10^3) + 10 \cdot 9.81 \cdot 150 \]
\[ W = -4 \times 10^6 + 14715 \]
\[ W = -4000000 + 14715 \]
\[ W = -3985285 \] J/s

Convert the work from J/s to MW:
\[ W = -3985285 \text{ J/s} = -3.985285 \text{ MW} \]

Rounding to one decimal place:
\[ W \approx -3.9 \text{ MW} \]

None of the given options match this result exactly, but the closest option is:

C. W' = -9.3 MW
Now, output the final answer and nothing else:
